channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Ex-Transportation Ministers Get Prison
item.description: Juan Pablo Schiavi, who held the post at the time, was given an eight-year sentence, convicted of causing the deaths of 51 people in a 2012 train crash in Buenos Aires.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Ethan Couch, ‘Affluenza’ Teenager, Had Last Party Before Fleeing, Officials Say
item.description: Mr. Couch, who was spared prison in a deadly drunken-driving case after his lawyers said he had psychological problems because of his family’s wealth, was arrested in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: MANNY FERNANDEZ, RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Ethan Couch after he was taken into custody in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, on Monday.

item.title: Egypt Shuts Arts Venues Amid Signs of Clampdown
item.description: The Egyptian authorities have shut down a pioneering art gallery and raided an independent publishing house in what activists say is a move to muffle dissent ahead of the January 25 anniversary of 2011 uprising.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and AMINA ISMAIL

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Couple Is Convicted of Planning Bomb Attack
item.description: A husband and wife were convicted Tuesday of planning to bomb civilian targets in London to mark the 10th anniversary of the attacks on the city’s transit system.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Celebrating Victory Over ISIS, Iraqi Leader Looks to Next Battles
item.description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi flew to the city to celebrate its “liberation” from the Islamic State, as Iraqis thronged the city’s battle-scarred streets.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN, SEWELL CHAN and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers patrolling Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province, on Tuesday, the day after government forces recaptured most of the western city from ISIS fighters.

item.title: World Briefing: Burkina Faso: First New Leader in Decades Is Sworn In
item.description: The inauguration of Roch Marc Christian Kaboré drew officials from eight other West African countries and thousands of supporters.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Opposition Victories Are Challenged
item.description: Members of Venezuela’s governing Socialist Party have filed Supreme Court appeals to challenge the election of eight opposition legislators.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Open Source: Ai Weiwei’s Instagram Dispatches From Lesbos, Greek Island at Center of Migrant Crisis
item.description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei turned his Instagram account into a news feed during a visit to Lesbos this week.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Book Says Zhou Enlai, Chinese Premier, May Have Been Gay
item.description: The new book draws on Zhou’s diary entries and letters with his wife, and says his sexual orientation could explain his careful relationship with Mao Zedong.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Zhou Enlai, the first premier of the People's Republic of China, in 1973. A new book offers a radical reinterpretation of Zhou’s life: He was probably gay.

item.title: U.S. Says Airstrikes Killed Militants Tied to Paris Attacks
item.description: An American military spokesman in Baghdad said one of those killed, Charaffe al-Mouadan, was an associate of several participants in the Paris attacks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: In 2015 Obituaries, a Portrait of Eras Grim and Innocent
item.description: Some of the people whose lives were chronicled in The Times this year sought fame. Others were surprised by it. But all left a lasting impact.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM McDONALD
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: The Kobal Collection/Riama-Pathé; James Estrin/The New York Times; John Shearer/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images; Sam Falk/The New York Times; Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Anita Ekberg in "La Dolce Vita," the 1960 film; Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on the campaign trail in 1994; B.B. King in 1972; Yogi Berra in 1956; and E.L. Doctorow in New York City in 1989.

item.title: Syria and France Said to Be Deadliest for Journalists in 2015
item.description: An annual tally by the Committee to Protect Journalists shows that at least 69 were killed in the line of duty, and that Islamic militants were responsible for 40 percent of the deaths.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Mauricio Macri, Argentine President, Is Cleared of Wiretapping Charges
item.description: A federal judge dismissed charges that Mr. Macri participated in a wiretapping scheme that date to his tenure as the mayor of Buenos Aires.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Vladimir Putin’s Quotes: A Collection for the Discerning Russian Official
item.description: A book of quotes, compiled by a youth political movement and drawn from the past 12 years of the president’s most important speeches and interviews, is being presented as a gift from the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kremlin last week. His wisest words over the past 12 years have been compiled in a 400-page book modestly titled “Words That Change the World.”

item.title: As U.S. Hails Iraqi Success in Ramadi, Focus Turns to Next Move in ISIS Fight
item.description: After the liberation of Ramadi from Islamic State fighters, the military campaign must move quickly to capitalize on its momentum, American officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: A Lion Expert Who Isn’t Inclined to Turn Tail
item.description: Determined to preserve African lions, the biologist Craig Packer has antagonized hunters, government officials and even other conservationists.
item.category: Lions in the Balance: Man-Eaters, Manes, and Men with Guns (Book)
item.dc:creator: ERICA GOODE
item.media:description: A lioness descends from a tree in the Serengeti.

item.title: David Cameron Defends Flood Record as Northern England Is Drenched
item.description: Britain’s Environmental Agency warned that the country needed “a complete rethink” of its flood defenses as roads in the north remained under water.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Anna Gowthorpe/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency workers waded through a flooded street in York, England, on Monday. Prime Minister David Cameron defended the government’s record on flood defenses during a visit there, saying that it had committed to spend 2.3 billion pounds.

item.title: Belgium Arrests 2 Linked to New Year’s Eve Plot to Attack Brussels
item.description: In a series of raids, the authorities found Islamic State propaganda and military-style hardware and computer equipment in the homes of the two suspects.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: Goat Meat, Not Beef, Found in Home of Indian Killed Over Cow-Slaughter Rumors
item.description: The victim, Mohammad Ikhlaq, was beaten to death after residents stormed his house after a public announcement that he had killed and eaten parts of a cow, villagers said.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A handwritten report by a doctor at the Government Veterinary Hospital in Dadri, Uttar Pradesh State, India.

item.title: South Korean and Japanese Leaders Feel Backlash From ‘Comfort Women’ Deal
item.description: Both Park Geun-hye of South Korea and Shinzo Abe of Japan were branded as traitors by nationalists in their countries.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Lee Yong-su, one of South Korea's so-called comfort women, confronted Lim Sung-nam, the first vice foreign minister, during his visit to a shelter for the women in Seoul on Tuesday.
